data.text: Any Experience with a Waxed Chain on Bikepacking Adventures?

Has anyone had any luck with using a waxed chain on your adventures. I am going to be riding for about 4 weeks and I would rather not be relubing and cleaning my chain. Risk of rotor contamination and needing to carry all that? Terrain light gravel, European summer conditions, mostly dry.
If you're going through dry conditions, get a good lube and you won't need to relube every day. I was out for 5 weeks and Rock and Roll Gold worked well for me.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: still going to have to use it multiple times though. Rock and roll is my go to generally, that or squirt.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: Not really. I did a 5 week, 1500 mile tour around Lake Erie a few years ago and noted how often I had to reapply wax based lube (White Lightning in my case). I did it 3 times at the beginning, about half way through and near the end. I got about 600 miles between applications.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: hmm that's not bad. I am thinking I will start with a hot waxed chain then top up with White lightning or squirt. Seems to be the least work option.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: once I am out there that is
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: I‚Äôve dabbled with hot wax in the past but shifted to liquid waxes because hot wax is just too much of a bother. I‚Äôve been using White Lightning for 25+ years and love the cleanliness of it as well as the easy application.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: yeah I figure I will give it a go, i will be using a fresh chain and it will need degreasing for White lightning anyway so it's not too much extra work to wax it. Plus It gets me to Munich where i can get lubes etc, saves me carrying it the first leg.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: If you do frequent long tours, consider getting a Rohloff hub. I'm getting one for my next bike. Lube free!
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: this is my first we will see how we go. It may end up being my last so...
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: Huh? You still need to lube your chain unless you are getting a belt drive.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: I'd just naturally assume a belt drive goes with a rohloff hub. Excuse any poor terminology.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: very few bikes come with the frame split required for belt drive. Majority of roll-offs are still run with chain.
data.author: J.c. Mcguirk

data.text: in which case, you can get a veer belt instead and just rivet it together. Moinudin is right, the nuclear solution for low maintenance is a belt drive and a rohloff.
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: nah you just carry a hack saw and mig welder
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: I'm following the Veer belts. They're pretty new and I appreciate those early adopters doing the testing for us üòé Personally, I do run Gates CDX/Rohloff on my Salsa Fargo and it's been amazing!
data.author: J.c. Mcguirk

data.text: They don't offer enough sprockets, and only round ones not oval or osymeytric. Even still it is just a little bunnyhop for the cyclist but a gargantually tremendous bounce for cycling.
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: First, I run a Rohloff. Second, he didn't mention a belt. The default for the vast majority of Rohloff users is still a chain. Yes, I know all about Veer and I get their emails but I think they're more focused on e-bikes.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: I started waxing my chains last year and have had really good results. Things practically never wear out by comparison now. That being said, a fresh wax is good for about 200 miles give or take depending on conditions and quality of application. So you'll still want a wax based drip lube to touch up with unless you're carrying a crock pot üòÇ I've been using white lightning clean ride because it's what I have and I know there's better, but it doesn't add oil to the chain so it's as simple as dipping it back in the croc when I can.
data.author: Jerry Duford

data.text: yeah I don't think I've got room for the Crockpot. So you can apply a wax lube over the top of a waxed chain, squirt or white lighting? No issues? do you need to clean the chain before you do that?
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: I've not had any issues doing it that way. You just want a non oil based (wet or semi wet lube). The wax based get along best with a waxed chain in my experience and keep it the cleanest. Squirt or white lightning clean ride come to mind but there are others
data.author: Jerry Duford

data.text: I'm going to be doing a fair bit more than 200 mile so like like wqxint wasn't the be all end all option for zero maintence
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: yeah if you're riding 4 weeks, you'll be doing maintenance on everything so it's pretty moot, but starting with a clean chain will make it lot easier to keep it clean. There's no way you can ride that long without cleaning and lubing. You may even be looking at more than one chain.
data.author: Jerry Duford

data.text: I'm sorry to pester you with questions but it is the first time I am going this far. When you say everything. I'm expecting to potentially replace cables, chains, brake pads. Is there anything else I should be aware of. Running hydraulic discs.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: Shouldn‚Äôt be a problem. White Lightning or Rock ‚Äòn‚Äô Roll use a solvent as the carrier and will just dissolve the existing wax. Squirt is probably more problematic because it is water based.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: hmm didn't know that. Given the bike will be outside and I won't have facilities to properly clean white lighting is probably a better option to avoid rust then.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: You shouldn‚Äôt need to replace much of anything on a 4 week tour. A chain should last 3000 to around 4000 miles. Put on a new one before you go and you should be good. Same with brake pads.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Everything that Jerry said except I prefer Squirt wax based lube for touch up. Wax immersion is the only way to go imo.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: sounds like it. I will start with two waxed chains and top up with lightning or squirt. I've had rust spots with squirt so I might go with lightning.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: Just carry cut up Scotch brite pads and scrub the old lube off at camp. Then be very attentive about the amount of lube you re-apply to your chain.
data.author: Steven Baker

data.text: Omg. Just carry a bit of oil. It‚Äôs not F1
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: Oil üôÑüòÖüòÇ
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: yes. Motor oil.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: Yeah, have fun with that. Bicycle abuse should be a crime üòÖüòÇ
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: 10w-40 on bike chains has worked for me and millions of others around the world for decades.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: Whatever dude. We all do things we shouldn't mention in public. You're on the wrong thread for sure. ‚úåÔ∏è
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: you should probably ask yourself why other people doing something different bothers you so much. Anyway if you are using motor oil o gaterentee your mechanic is complaining about it.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: I‚Äôm not bothered at all. You‚Äôre the one having a hissy fit because since 1903 people have been using whatever oil is available on chains without issue but now the trendy wax or whatever is mandatory. Go ride your bike
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: you are the one having a hissy fit 200000 years people have been walking, most of that without shoes but now the trendy bike or car is mandatory. Just walk. I was just exploring options that may make my trip easier, looking for advice from people who have actually tried it. There is no need to be rude as you said, just ride dont worry about what others are doing.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem
Sean McLenidoodle

data.text: You guys clean your chain?
data.author: Jay Tee

data.text: well that is what I am trying to avoid a good waxing should mean wipe reapply and move on
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: You can expect up to 1000 miles between any cleanups (hot water rinse) and rewaxing. If really dirty and wet little less. Very recommended. I don't use anything else and converted all my bikes to dry hot waxed clean to touch chains. Never greasy fingers again!
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: well that is slightly further than my trip so perfect
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: are you not applying anything in those 1600km or so. Just forgetting about it?
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: on a road bike. Nothing. No touch. No clean. Chain stays cleaner than the bike as crazy as it sounds
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: the only recommendation (always good idea) to carry a spare quick link just in case. Also wax it. And be sure to meticulous degrease everything the chain touches and sure the chain. Sprockes, pulleys...
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: I'm planning on having two new chains one on the bike and one in my bag, both freshly waxed new cassette too. But I will do. Thanks for the heads up. I don't trust quick links though, chain pins only for me. I keep breaking them. Too many watts apparently.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: Percy's the man! He's local to me and he's out riding everywhere, all the time. Ultrasonic clean of the chain before a crockpot dunk in some hot paraffin and you'll be good to go. I just cleaned and redunked my trainer chain last week and the drive train is silent. Good luck and have a safe trip. üëçüèª
data.author: Cat Fish

data.text: have a great trip.
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: thanks everyone
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: one additional questio as you seem to the the go to guy when it comes to wax, do you get the waxes with any additives or just 100% parafin off Amazon?
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: you can add ultra fine PTFE (Teflon) powder. 25g on 500g wax.
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: Think I've got a plan, start hot waxed and top up with a wax based lube as needed, thanks team
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: I'd be very careful with that as solvents may attract dirt and move it in the links. So far I stayed away from that. Thought about it and have a bottle of that stuff. But environmentally nasty solvents... May be a emergency backup on the way.
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: yeah it will come down to how the condition of the chain. I will play it by ear
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: Exactly like that. After 1600km you'll notice it getting a bit noisier. But dry and clean rocks.
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: even this... no issues. But use a rust proof/ resistant quality chain!
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: Washed clean by heavy rain... and eventually a final rinse with a water bottle. Done.
data.author: Percy Zahl

data.text: White Lightning Clean is a great product.
data.author: Mark Krause

data.text: pretty stoked on squirt for my chain, though its the only waxed based thing ived tried. it applies more like a wet lube, but last longer and less messy. something i heard lately which kindof blew my mind was that only the inside of the chain needs to stay lubricated... no wonder they always say to wipe off the chain after application.
data.author: Lucas Ehster

data.text: I've been using squirt for a bit but I keep finding rust spots the day after i use it, which is a little disconcerting
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: did you clean and dry your chain before hand?
data.author: Lucas Ehster

data.text: I did. Followed the instructions properly, as far as I am aware. Might be the humidity and temperature where I live
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: must not have let it dry long enough. try a hairdryer or a good patch of sun for awhile
data.author: Lucas Ehster

data.text: It's possible
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: yep, it is great stuff. Will never use oil again.
data.author: Peter Noble
